comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: A similar, although non-identical, indicator board is held by the Powerhouse Museum and holds a dominant position in the transport display at the museum's Ultimo premises: www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=212227

comment.author: 28304000@N00
comment._content: This is the arrivals board.  It was removed much earlier on than the departures board.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lifeasdaddy] Thanks for the PHM link. It gives a nice history of the board (removed in 1982) and its significance as a 'meeting place'. We have a copy of that photo, too.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: Now this picture right here demonstrates one of the pitfalls of digital imaging,  either the scanner setting or the image compression has removed the ability to read the names on the board which I am sure were visible on the original.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] This is a 75dpi copy of the 'master' image that we scan.  We don't tend to upload these original digital images to Flickr but are always happy to add a larger version (if not the 'master' file) of an image for people who'd like to view more details. 

I've replaced this with a larger version for you.

AB

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/albert3801] I wonder why there was a change? Were they so relieved to see that the train arrived? ;-)

I noticed that the now discontinued "Loop line" was operating on the South line then.

The text font used seems to place it pre WW2?
